column4: Hey ubuntu people. I have a partition (/dev/sda2) and apparently this is "lvm" which I understand is some kind of logical partition. I cant mount it with mount on commandline, any idea how I can?
/dev/sda2 is not lvm
well, that's a relief. What is it then?
the second partition on your primary disk
yeah, but when I try to mount it, mount says: "mount: unknown filesystem type 'LVM2_member'"
that means that partition is included in a LVM group
okay, and that somehow prevents me from mounting it?
yes, as it's does not contains a file system it's self as a device
so practically, all data there is lost?
not at all no
you need to mount the logical volume, from the volume gruop that contains /dev/sda2
Huzzah! :). Please tell me, how can I get it back?
oh oh... how do I figure that one out?
do a "vgdisplay -v" and see which group contains /dev/sda2 - I'd guess vg00
that good, although the worry is that there is no volume groups found
I assume a vgdisplay VolGroup00 doesn't do anything
aye, nothing. I do have to mention though that this is from a linux installation a long time ago
well, looks like that volume group may have been removed, you can try a "vgscan" see if it finds anything
immidiately: no volume groups found
that volume group is gone then I'm afraid
and the data is lost anyway?
sounds like it now
if the volume group is gone, then I'd expect the logical volumes to also be gone
okay thanks :). I'll try something else, but then I think ill have to format it
